===''Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone'' (2001)=== <!-- Please note that, per consensus, "Philosopher's Stone" is used instead of "Sorcerer's Stone". --> {{Main|Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone (film)}} {{Dablink|Known in India and the United States as '''Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone'''}} [[File:David Heyman1.jpg|thumb|upright|David Heyman has produced every film in the Wizarding World.]] [[Harry Potter (character)|Harry Potter]], a seemingly ordinary eleven-year-old boy, is actually a [[Wizard (fantasy)|wizard]] and survivor of [[Lord Voldemort]]'s attempted rise to power. Harry is rescued from his unkind [[Muggle]] relatives and takes his place at [[Hogwarts|Hogwarts School of Witchcraft and Wizardry]], where he and his friends [[Ron Weasley]] and [[Hermione Granger]] become entangled in the mystery of the [[Philosopher's Stone]], which is being kept within the school.
In October 1998, [[Warner Bros.]] purchased the film rights to the first four novels of the ''[[Harry Potter]]'' fantasy series by [[J. K. Rowling]] for a seven-figure sum,<ref name="HPFilmRights" /> after a pitch from producer [[David Heyman]].<ref name="HeymanPitch" /> Warner Bros. took particular notice of Rowling's wishes and thoughts about the films when drafting her contract. One of her principal stipulations was that they be shot in Britain with an all-British cast,<ref name="BritishCast" /> which has been generally adhered to. On 8 August 2000, the virtually unknown [[Daniel Radcliffe]] and newcomers [[Rupert Grint]] and [[Emma Watson]] were selected to play Harry Potter, Ron Weasley and Hermione Granger.<ref name="TrioCast" /> [[Chris Columbus (filmmaker)|Chris Columbus]] was hired to direct the film adaptation of ''[[Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone|Philosopher's Stone]],''<ref name="Columbus" /> with [[Steve Kloves]] selected to write the screenplay.<ref name="KlovesScreenplay" /> Filming began on 29 September 2000 at [[Warner Bros. Studios, Leavesden|Leavesden Film Studios]] and concluded on 23 March 2001,<ref name="HP1Filming" /><ref name="HPLeavesden" /> with final work being done in July.<ref name="HP1PostYahoo" /> [[Principal photography]] took place on 2 October 2000 at [[North Yorkshire]]'s [[Goathland railway station]].<ref name="HP1PPhotography" /> Warner Bros. had initially planned to release the film over 4 July 2001 weekend, making for such a short production window that several proposed directors removed themselves from consideration. Because of time constraints, the date was put back, and ''[[Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone (film)|Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone]]'' was released in the United Kingdom and the United States on 16 November 2001.<ref name="HP1Release" />
===''Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets'' (2002)=== {{Main|Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets (film)}} Harry, Ron, and Hermione return to Hogwarts for their second year, but a [[Hogwarts#Chamber of Secrets|mysterious chamber]], hidden in the school, is opened leaving students and ghosts petrified by an unknown agent. They must solve the mystery of the chamber, and discover its entrance to find and defeat the true culprit.
Columbus and Kloves returned as director, and screenwriter for the film adaptation of ''[[Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets|Chamber of Secrets]]''.<ref name="Columbus2" /><ref name="Kloves" /> Just three days after the wide release of the first film, production began on 19 November 2001<ref name="HP2Production" /> in [[Surrey]], England, with filming continuing [[Filming location|on location]] on the [[Isle of Man]] and at several other locations in Great Britain. [[Leavesden Film Studios]] in London made several scenes for Hogwarts.<ref name="HP2FilmingEnd" /><ref name="HP2Locations" /> Principal photography concluded in the summer of 2002.<ref name="HP2FilmingEnd" /> The film spent until early October in [[post-production]].<ref name="HP2Post" /> ''[[Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets (film)|Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets]]'' premiered in the United Kingdom on 3 November 2002 before its wide release on 15 November, one year after the ''Philosopher's Stone''.<ref name="HP2PremiereUK" /><ref name="HPTotalBOM" />
===''Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban'' (2004)=== {{Main|Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban (film)}} A mysterious convict, [[Sirius Black]], escapes from [[Azkaban]] and sets his sights on Hogwarts, where [[dementor]]s are stationed to protect Harry and his peers. Harry learns more about his past and his connection with the escaped prisoner.
Columbus, the director of the two previous films, decided not to return to helm the third instalment,<!--British English spells this word with one "l", not two--><ref name="Columbus2" /> but remained as a producer alongside Heyman.<ref name="CuaronConnection"/> Warner Bros. then drew up a three-name, short list for Columbus' replacement, which comprised [[Callie Khouri]], [[Kenneth Branagh]] (who played [[Gilderoy Lockhart]] in ''Chamber of Secrets'') and the eventual director [[Alfonso Cuarón]].<ref name="Cuaron" /> Cuarón was initially nervous about accepting the job having not read any of the books, or seen the films, but later signed on after reading the series and connecting immediately with the story.<ref name="CuaronNervous" /><ref name="CuaronConnection" /> [[Michael Gambon]] replaced [[Richard Harris]], who played [[Albus Dumbledore]] in the previous two films, after Harris's death in October 2002.<ref name="Gambon" /><ref name="HarrisDeath" /> Gambon was unconcerned with bettering or copying Harris, instead provided his own interpretation, including using a slight Irish accent for the role.<ref name="HP3castinterviews" /> He completed his scenes in three weeks.<ref name="GambonFilming" /> [[Gary Oldman]] was cast in the key role of Sirius Black in February 2003.<ref name="HP3FilmingBegin"/> Principal photography began on 24 February 2003,<ref name="HP3FilmingBegin" /> at Leavesden Film Studios, and concluded in October 2003.<ref name="HP3FilmingEnd" /> ''[[Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban (film)|Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban]]'' premiered on 23 May 2004 in New York.<ref name="HP3Premiere" /> It was released in the United Kingdom on 31 May, and in the United States on 4 June.<ref name="HP3Release" /> It was the first film in the series to be released in both conventional and [[IMAX]] theatres.<ref name="HP3IMAX" />
===''Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire'' (2005)=== {{Main|Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire (film)}} After the [[Quidditch]] World Cup, Harry arrives back at Hogwarts and finds himself entered in the [[Triwizard Tournament]], a challenging competition involving completing three dangerous tasks. Harry is forced to compete with three other wizards chosen by the [[Goblet of Fire]] {{snd}} [[Fleur Delacour]], [[Viktor Krum]], and [[Cedric Diggory]].
In August 2003, British film director [[Mike Newell (director)|Mike Newell]] was chosen to direct the film after ''Prisoner of Azkaban'' director Alfonso Cuarón announced that he would not direct the sequel. Heyman returned to produce, and Kloves again wrote the screenplay.<ref name="Newell" /> Principal photography began on 4 May 2004.<ref name="HP4PPhotography" /> Scenes involving the film's principal actors began shooting on 25 June 2004 at England's Leavesden Film Studios.<ref name="HP4FilmingBegin" /><ref name="HP4Production" /> ''[[Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire (film)|Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire]]'' premiered on 6 November 2005 in London,<ref name="HP4Premiere" /> and was released in the United Kingdom and the United States on 18 November.<ref name="HP4Release" /> ''Goblet of Fire'' was the first film in the series to receive a [[PG-13]] rating by the [[Motion Picture Association of America]] (MPAA) for "sequences of fantasy violence and frightening images,"<ref name="HP4ratingMPAA" /> M by the [[Australian Classification Board]] (ACB),<ref name="HP4ratingACB" /> and a 12A by the [[British Board of Film Classification]] (BBFC) for its dark themes, fantasy violence, threat and frightening images.<ref name="HP4ratingBBFC" />
===''Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix'' (2007)=== {{Main|Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix (film)}} [[File:David Yates by Gage Skidmore.jpg|thumb|upright|David Yates has directed every film in the franchise since ''Order of the Phoenix''.]] Harry returns for his fifth year at Hogwarts and discovers that the [[Fictional universe of Harry Potter|Wizarding World]] is in denial of Voldemort's return. He takes matters into his own hands and starts a [[Dumbledore's Army|secret organisation]] to stand up against the regime of Hogwarts' "High Inquisitor" [[Dolores Umbridge]], as well as to learn practical [[Defence Against the Dark Arts]] (D.A.D.A) for the forthcoming battle.<ref name=PhoenixSynopsis />
Daniel Radcliffe confirmed he would return as Harry Potter in May 2005,<ref name="HP5Radcliffe" /> with Rupert Grint, Emma Watson, [[Matthew Lewis (actor)|Matthew Lewis]] ([[Neville Longbottom]]), and [[Bonnie Wright]] ([[Ginny Weasley]]) confirmed to return in November 2005.<ref name="HP5Grint" /><ref name="HP5Watson" /><ref name="HP5Lewis" /><ref name="HP5Wright" /> In February 2006, [[Helen McCrory]] was cast as [[Bellatrix Lestrange]],<ref name="McCrory" /> but dropped out due to her pregnancy. In May 2006, [[Helena Bonham Carter]] was cast in her place.<ref name="BonhamCarter" /> [[Ralph Fiennes]] reprises his role as Lord Voldemort.<ref name="HP5Fiennes" /> British television director [[David Yates]] was chosen to direct the film after ''Goblet of Fire'' director Newell, as well as [[Jean-Pierre Jeunet]], [[Guillermo del Toro]], [[Matthew Vaughn]] and [[Mira Nair]], turned down offers.<ref name="HP5Director" /><ref name="HP5Director2" /> Kloves, the screenwriter of the first four Harry ''Potter'' films, had other commitments and [[Michael Goldenberg]], who had been considered for screenwriter of the series' first film, filled in to write the script.<ref name="Goldenberg" /> Principal photography began on 7 February 2006, and concluded at the start of December 2006.<ref name="HP5FilmingBegin" /><ref name="HP5TLC" /> Filming was put on a two-month hiatus starting in May 2006 so Radcliffe could sit his [[GCE Advanced Level|A/S Levels]] and Watson could sit her [[General Certificate of Secondary Education|GCSE]] exams.<ref name="HP5FilmingHiatus" /> Live-action filming took place in England and Scotland for exterior locations and at Leavesden Film Studios for interior locations.<ref name="HP5Locations" /><ref name="HP5Locations2" /><ref name="HP5Locations3" /> ''[[Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix (film)|Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix]]'' had its world premiere on 28 June 2007 in Tokyo, Japan,<ref name="HP5TokyoPremiere" /> and a UK premiere on 3 July 2007 at the [[Odeon Leicester Square]] in London.<ref name="HP5UKPremiere" /> The film was released in the United Kingdom on 12 July,<ref name="HP5UKRelease" /> and the United States on 11 July.<ref name="HP5USRelease" />
===''Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince'' (2009)=== {{Main|Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince (film)}} Voldemort and his Death Eaters are increasing their terror upon the Wizarding and Muggle worlds. Needing him for an important reason, Headmaster Dumbledore persuades his old friend [[Horace Slughorn]] to return to his prior post at Hogwarts. During Slughorn's Potions class, Harry takes possession of a strangely annotated school textbook, previously owned by the "Half-Blood Prince".<ref name="HBPSynopsis" />
In July 2007, it was announced that Yates would return as director.<ref name="Yates2" /> Kloves returned to write the screenplay after skipping out of the fifth film, with Heyman and [[David Barron (film producer)|David Barron]] back as producers.<ref name="HBPCast" /> Watson considered not returning for the film,<ref name="HBPWatson" /> but eventually signed on after Warner Bros. moved the production schedule to accommodate her exam dates.<ref name="HBPWatsonEducation" /> Principal photography began on 24 September 2007,<ref name="HBPFilmingBegin" /> and concluded on 17 May 2008.<ref name="HBPFilmingEnd" /> Though Radcliffe, Gambon and [[Jim Broadbent]] (Slughorn) started shooting in late September 2007, other cast members started much later: Watson did not begin until December 2007, [[Alan Rickman]] ([[Severus Snape]]) until January 2008, and Bonham Carter until February 2008.<ref name="HBPFilmingWatsonRickman" /><ref name="HBPFilmingBonhamCarter" /> ''[[Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince (film)|Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince]]'' had its world premiere on 6 July 2009 in Tokyo, Japan,<ref name="HBPTokyoPremiere" /> and was released in the United Kingdom and the United States on 15 July.<ref name="HBPWorldRelease" />
===''Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows – Part 1'' (2010)=== {{Main|Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows – Part 1}} Harry, Ron, and Hermione leave Hogwarts behind and set out to find and destroy Lord Voldemort's secret to immortality – the [[Horcrux]]es. The trio undergo a long journey with many obstacles in their path including Death Eaters, Snatchers, the mysterious [[Deathly Hallows (object)|Deathly Hallows]], and Harry's connection with the Dark Lord's mind becoming ever stronger.<ref name="DH1Synopsis" />
Originally scheduled for a single theatrical release, on 13 March 2008, Warner Bros. announced that the film adaptation of [[Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows|''Deathly Hallows'']] would be split into two parts to do justice to the book and out of respect for its fans. Yates, director of the previous two films, was confirmed to return as director, and Kloves was confirmed as screenwriter.<ref name="DHTwoPart" /> For the first time in the series, Rowling was credited as a producer alongside Heyman and Barron, however Yates noted that her participation in the filmmaking process did not change from the previous films.<ref name="DHRowlingProducer" /><ref name="DHProducers" /> Pre-production began on 26 January 2009,<ref name="DHPreProd" /> while principal photography began on 19 February at Leavesden Studios, where the previous six instalments were filmed. [[Pinewood Studios]] became the second studio location for shooting the seventh film.<ref name="HPLeavesden" /><ref name="DHLeavesdenPinewood" /> The premiere of ''[[Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows – Part 1]]'' was held on 11 November 2010, at the [[Empire, Leicester Square]] in London, and the film was released in the United Kingdom and the United States on 19 November.<ref name="DH1PremiereRelease" />
===''Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows – Part 2'' (2011)=== {{Main|Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows – Part 2}} [[File:Daniel Radcliffe, Emma Watson & Rupert Grint colour.jpg|thumb|left|Daniel Radcliffe, Emma Watson and Rupert Grint at the world premiere of ''Deathly Hallows – Part 2'' on 7 July 2011 at Trafalgar Square in London.]] Harry, Ron, and Hermione continue their search to find and destroy the remaining Horcruxes, as Harry prepares for the final battle against Voldemort.<ref name="DH2Synopsis" />
The film was announced in March 2008 as ''[[Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows – Part 2]]'', the [[Production of Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows|second of two cinematic parts]]. It was also revealed that Yates would direct the film and that Kloves would write the screenplay.<ref name="DHTwoPart" /> Kloves started work on the second part's script in April 2009, after the first part's script was completed.<ref name="DHKlovesScript" /> ''Deathly Hallows – Part 2'' was filmed [[Back to back film production|back-to-back]] with ''Deathly Hallows – Part 1'' from 19 February 2009 to 12 June 2010,<ref name="DHfilming" /><ref name="HPLeavesden" /><ref name="DH2wraps" /> and treated as if it were one film during principal photography.<ref name="DHoneFilm" /> Reshoots were confirmed to begin in the winter of 2010 for the film's final, and epilogue scenes, which had originally taken place at [[London King's Cross railway station|London King's Cross station]]. The filming took place at Leavesden Film Studios on 21 December 2010,<ref name="DHreshoots" /> marking the end of the ''Harry Potter'' series after ten years of filming.<ref name="HPwraps" />
The film had its world premiere on 7 July 2011 in [[Trafalgar Square]] in London,<ref name="DH2UKPremiereRelease" /> and a U.S. premiere on 11 July at [[Lincoln Center]] in New York City.<ref name="DH2USPremiere" /> Although filmed in 2D, the film was converted into [[3D film|3D]] in post-production and was released in both [[RealD 3D]] and IMAX 3D,<ref name="DH2Imax3D" /> becoming the first film in the series to be released in this format.<ref name="DH2_3D" /> The film was released on 15 July in the United Kingdom and the United States.<ref name="DH2UKPremiereRelease" />

===''Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them'' (2016)=== {{Main|Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them (film)}} [[File:J. K. Rowling 2010.jpg|thumb|right|upright|''Harry Potter'' author J. K. Rowling wrote and produced the two films in the ''Fantastic Beasts'' series and produced the last two ''Harry Potter'' films.]] In 1926, [[Newt Scamander]] arrives in New York City with his magically expanded briefcase which houses a number of dangerous creatures and their habitats. When some creatures escape from his briefcase, Newt must battle to correct the mistake, and the horrors of the resultant increase in violence, fear, and tension felt between magical and non-magical people ([[Muggles|No-Maj]]).<ref name="FBSynopsis" />
On 12 September 2013, Warner Bros. announced that J. K. Rowling was writing a script based on her book ''[[Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them]]'' and the adventures of its fictional author Newt Scamander, set seventy years before the adventures of Harry Potter. The film would mark her screenwriting debut and is planned as the first movie in a new series.<ref name="FBScriptBook" /> According to Rowling, after Warner Bros. suggested an adaptation, she wrote a rough draft of the script in twelve days. She said, "It wasn't a great draft but it did show the shape of how it might look. So that is how it all started."<ref name="FBDraft" /> In March 2014, it was revealed that a trilogy was scheduled with the first instalment<!--British English spells this word with one "l", not two--> set in New York.<ref name="FBTrilogy" /> The film sees the return of producer David Heyman, as well as writer Steve Kloves, both veterans of the ''Potter'' film series.<ref name="FBHeyman" /><ref name="FBProds" /> In June 2015, [[Eddie Redmayne]] was cast in the lead role of [[Newt Scamander]], the Wizarding World's preeminent magizoologist.<ref name="RedmayneCast" /> Other cast members include: [[Katherine Waterston]] as Tina Goldstein, [[Alison Sudol]] as Queenie Goldstein, [[Dan Fogler]] as Jacob Kowalski, [[Ezra Miller]] as Credence Barebone, [[Samantha Morton]] as Mary Lou Barebone, [[Jenn Murray]] as Chastity Barebone, Faith Wood-Blagrove as Modesty Barebone, and [[Colin Farrell]] as Percival Graves.<ref name="FBCast" /> Principal photography began on 17 August 2015, at Warner Bros. Studios, Leavesden.<ref name="Aug2015Deadline" /> After two months, the production moved to [[St George's Hall, Liverpool|St George's Hall]] in Liverpool, which was transformed into 1920s New York City.<ref name="FBLiverpool" /> ''[[Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them (film)|Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them]]'' was released worldwide on 18 November 2016.<ref name="FBRelease" />
===''Fantastic Beasts: The Crimes of Grindelwald'' (2018)=== {{Main|Fantastic Beasts: The Crimes of Grindelwald}} A few months have passed since the events of ''Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them,'' [[Gellert Grindelwald]] has escaped imprisonment and has begun gathering followers to his cause{{snd}}elevating wizards above all non-magical beings. Dumbledore must seek help from his former student Newt to put a stop to Grindelwald.<ref name="FB2FilmingBegin" />
The film was announced in March 2014 as the second instalment<!--British English spells this word with one "l", not two--> in the series.<ref name="FBTrilogy" /> In October 2016, it was revealed that Yates and Rowling would return as director, and screenwriter and co-producer, and Redmayne would be returning to play the lead role of Newt Scamander in all the series' films.<ref name="FBFiveFilms" /> In November 2016, it was confirmed that [[Johnny Depp]] will have a starring role in the sequel, reprising his role as Gellert Grindelwald from the first instalment.<ref name="Depp" /> Later that same month it was also announced that Albus Dumbledore would be appearing in future instalments,<!--British English spells this word with one "l", not two--> albeit with a younger actor for the prequel film series.<ref name="FBDumbledore" /> In April 2017, it was confirmed that [[Jude Law]] had been cast for the role.<ref name="Law" /> The second film took place in the United Kingdom and Paris.<ref name="FB2Location" /> Principal photography began on 3 July 2017, at Warner Bros. Studios, Leavesden,<ref name="FB2FilmingBegin" /> and concluded on 20 December 2017.<ref name="FB2FilmingEnd" /> ''[[Fantastic Beasts: The Crimes of Grindelwald]]'' was released on 16 November 2018.<ref name="FB2Release" />
===Untitled third ''Fantastic Beasts'' film (2020)=== The third instalment<!--this is correct British English spelling--> is scheduled to be released on 20 November 2020.<ref name="Aug2016Variety" /><ref name="FB3Release" />
=== Other sequels === In October 2016, Rowling announced that the ''Fantastic Beasts'' film series would comprise five films.<ref name="FBFiveFilms" /> In November 2016, Rowling confirmed that the series' story would consist of a sequence of events that occurred between the years of 1926 and 1945.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.inverse.com/article/24129-fantastic-beasts-timeline-confirmed-jk-rowling-grindelwald-dumbledore |title=J.K. Rowling Just Confirmed 'Fantastic Beasts' Will End in WWII |last=Logan |first=Megan |website=[[Inverse (website)|Inverse]] |date=21 November 2016 |accessdate=20 October 2017 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6ltlRr4t0?url=http://deadline.com/2014/10/kevin-tsujihara-time-warner-investor-day-warner-bros-ceo-presentation-851823/ |archivedate=9 November 2016 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }}</ref>
==''Harry Potter and the Cursed Child''== {{Main|Harry Potter and the Cursed Child}} In December 2013, J. K. Rowling announced that she was working on a ''Harry Potter''–based play,<ref name="HPPlayDevelop" /> and in June 2015 it was officially titled ''[[Harry Potter and the Cursed Child]]''.<ref name="CCPlayTitle" /> The two-part, [[West End theatre|West End]] [[stage play]], written by British playwright [[Jack Thorne (writer)|Jack Thorne]] is based on an original story by Thorne, [[John Tiffany]] and Rowling. It is directed by Tiffany with choreography by [[Steven Hoggett]], set design by [[Christine Jones (scenic designer)|Christine Jones]], costume design by Katrina Lindsay, lighting design by Neil Austin, music by [[Imogen Heap]], and sound design by Gareth Fry.<ref name="CursedChildAbout" /> The story begins nineteen years<!-- The play was released nine years after the seventh book, but takes place 19 years later (within the context of the story) --> after the events of ''Deathly Hallows'' and follows Harry Potter, now a [[Ministry of Magic]] employee, and his younger son [[List of supporting Harry Potter characters#Albus Potter|Albus Severus Potter]], who is about to attend Hogwarts.<ref name="CCSynopsis" /> On 20 December 2015, it was announced that [[Jamie Parker]], [[Noma Dumezweni]] and [[Paul Thornley (actor)|Paul Thornley]] would play Harry Potter, Hermione Granger and Ron Weasley.<ref name="CCTrioCast" /> The play debuted at the [[Palace Theatre, London]] on 7 June 2016 in previews, with the official opening on 30 July.<ref name="CCPreviewsPremiere" /> The script was released in book form the day after the play's world premiere.<ref name="ScriptBook" /> The play opened on [[Broadway theatre|Broadway]] at the redesigned [[Lyric Theatre (1998 New York City)|Lyric Theatre]], New York City on 22 April 2018.<ref name="BroadwayOpening" /> Parker, Dumezweni, and Thornley reprised their roles on Broadway with [[Poppy Miller]], [[Sam Clemmett]], [[Alex Price]], and [[Anthony Boyle]] also reprising their roles as [[Dumbledore's Army#Ginny Weasley|Ginny Potter]], Albus Potter, [[Draco Malfoy]], and [[Draco Malfoy#Epilogue|Scorpius Malfoy]], respectively.<ref name="CCBroadwayCast" />

==Reception== {{hatnote|For more details on the reception of each film, see the "Reception" section on each film's article.}}
===Box office performance=== {{As of|2018}}, the Wizarding World films have collectively grossed over $9 billion at the global box office, making it the [[List of highest-grossing film series#Highest-grossing franchises and film series|third-highest-grossing film franchise]] of all time behind the [[Marvel Cinematic Universe]] [[List of Marvel Cinematic Universe films|films]] and the ''[[Star Wars]]'' films. Each film has grossed over $790 million, and all but ''Prisoner of Azkaban'' and ''Fantastic Beasts'' at some point ranked among the [[List of highest-grossing film series|ten highest-grossing films of all time]]. The [[Harry Potter (film series)|''Harry Potter'' films]] are the highest-grossing series based on a single property, earning over $7.7 billion at the box office;<ref name="AllTimeDomesticBOM" /><ref name="HPTotalBOM" /> ''Harry Potter'' has also generated at least $3.5 billion in home video revenue, taking total consumer spending on the films to over $11 billion.<ref name="TheNumbersHP" /> ''Harry Potter'' also has a series average of over $1 billion per film when adjusted for inflation.<ref name="HPSeriesAverage" />
''Deathly Hallows – Part 2'' grossed over $1.3 billion becoming the third-highest-grossing film of all time, the highest-grossing film in the Wizarding World franchise, and the [[2011 in film|highest-grossing film of 2011]].<ref name="BOM2011highest" /> In the United States and Canada, it set a single-day and opening-weekend record, with $91,071,119 and $169,189,427.<ref name="DH2OpeningDay" /><ref name="DH2OpeningWeekend" /> In addition, the film set a worldwide opening-weekend record with $483,189,427.<ref name="DH2WorldwideDebut" /><ref name="TheNumbersDH2" /> ''Philosopher's Stone'' and ''Goblet of Fire'' were also the [[2001 in film|highest-grossing films of 2001]] and [[2005 in film|2005]];<ref name="BOM2001highest" /><ref name="BOM2005highest" /> while ''Chamber of Secrets'', ''Prisoner of Azkaban'', ''Order of the Phoenix'', and ''Half-Blood Prince'' were the [[2002 in film|second highest-grossing films of 2002]], [[2004 in film|2004]], [[2007 in film|2007]], and [[2009 in film|2009]].<ref name="BOM2002highest" /><ref name="BOM2004highest" /><ref name="BOM2007highest" /><ref name="BOM2009highest" /> ''Deathly Hallows – Part 1'' was the [[2010 in film|third-highest-grossing film of 2010]], (behind ''[[Toy Story 3]]'' and ''[[Alice in Wonderland (2010 film)|Alice in Wonderland]])'',<ref name="BOM2010highest" /> and ''Fantastic Beasts'' was the [[2016 in film|eighth-highest-grossing film of 2016]].<ref name="BOM2016highest" />

===Critical and public response=== All the films have been a success commercially and the majority a success critically, making the franchise one of the major Hollywood "tent-poles" akin to ''[[James Bond in film|James Bond]]'', ''[[Star Wars]]'', ''[[Indiana Jones (franchise)|Indiana Jones]]'', and ''[[Pirates of the Caribbean (film series)|Pirates of the Caribbean]]''. The ''Harry Potter'' series is noted by audiences for growing visually [[dark fantasy|darker]] and more mature as each film was released.<ref name="ColumbusDark" /><ref name="TimeDarker" /><ref name="ReutersDark" /><ref name="DarkMoody" />

===Accolades===
====Academy Awards==== Seven of the nine films were nominated for a total of 14 [[Academy Awards]]. ''Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them'' won for [[Academy Award for Best Costume Design|Best Costume Design]] in [[89th Academy Awards|2017]], becoming the first film in the Wizarding World to win an Academy Award.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2017/02/27/oscars-2017-fantastic-beasts-and-where-to-find-them-wins-first-oscar-for-harry-potter-franchise |title=Oscars 2017: Fantastic Beasts Wins First Academy Award for Harry Potter Franchise |last=Dornbush |first=Jonathon |date=26 February 2017 |publisher=[[IGN]] |language=en-US |accessdate=27 February 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170227023421/http://www.ign.com/articles/2017/02/27/oscars-2017-fantastic-beasts-and-where-to-find-them-wins-first-oscar-for-harry-potter-franchise |archivedate=27 February 2017 }}</ref> Before the win in 2017, the franchise was the most-[[wikt:snub|snubbed]], top-grossing franchise of all time at the Academy Awards, with 12 nominations and zero wins.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.eonline.com/news/297110/thanks-academy-oscars-make-harry-potter-most-snubbed-franchise-of-all-time |title=Thanks, Academy: Oscars Make Harry Potter Most-Snubbed Franchise of All-Time |last=Ryan |first=Joal |date=27 February 2012 |work=[[E! Online]] |accessdate=5 July 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160303222120/http://www.eonline.com/news/297110/thanks-academy-oscars-make-harry-potter-most-snubbed-franchise-of-all-time |archivedate=3 March 2016 }}</ref>

====British Academy Film Awards==== The franchise has earned a total of 32 nominations at the [[British Academy Film Awards]] presented at the annual [[British Academy of Film and Television Arts|BAFTAs]], winning three. At the [[64th British Academy Film Awards]] in February 2011, Rowling, producers Heyman and Barron, along with directors Yates, Newell and Cuarón collected the [[BAFTA Outstanding British Contribution to Cinema Award|Michael Balcon Award for Outstanding British Contribution to Cinema]] in honour of the ''Harry Potter'' film series.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/entertainment-arts-12353795 |title=Harry Potter franchise to get Outstanding BAFTA award |publisher=[[BBC Online]] |date=3 February 2011 |accessdate=3 February 2011 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110204111609/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/entertainment-arts-12353795 |archivedate=4 February 2011 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bafta.org/awards/film/outstanding-british-contribution-to-cinema-the-harry-potter-films,1631,BA.html |title=Outstanding British Contribution to Cinema in 2011 – The Harry Potter films |publisher=[[British Academy of Film and Television Arts]] (BAFTA) |date=3 February 2011 |accessdate=3 February 2011 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110206001409/http://www.bafta.org/awards/film/outstanding-british-contribution-to-cinema-the-harry-potter-films%2C1631%2CBA.html |archivedate=6 February 2011 |deadurl=yes }}</ref> The ''Harry Potter'' series was also recognised by the [[Britannia Awards|BAFTA Los Angeles Britannia Awards]], with Yates winning the Britannia Award for Artistic Excellence in Directing for his four ''Harry Potter'' films.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://losangeles.broadwayworld.com/article/BAFTA-Honors-John-Lasseter-and-David-Yates-1130-20110628 |title=BAFTA Honors John Lasseter and David Yates 11/30 |publisher=[[Broadway Worldwide]] (Los Angeles) |date=28 June 2011 |accessdate=28 June 2011 |quote=The worldwide success of Mr. Lasseter for Walt Disney and Pixar Animation Studios and Mr. Yates' contribution to the final four parts of the 'Harry Potter' franchise makes them global wizards in their own right, and are delighted to honor these remarkable filmmakers with this year's Britannia Award. |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120120084528/http://losangeles.broadwayworld.com/article/BAFTA-Honors-John-Lasseter-and-David-Yates-1130-20110628 |archivedate=20 January 2012 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/awards/2011/06/john-lasseter-and-david-yates-set-to-be-honored-by-bafta-los-angeles-.html |title=John Lasseter and David Yates set to be honored by BAFTA Los Angeles |work=[[Los Angeles Times]] |date=28 June 2011 |accessdate=28 June 2011 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110703082314/http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/awards/2011/06/john-lasseter-and-david-yates-set-to-be-honored-by-bafta-los-angeles-.html |archivedate=3 July 2011 }}</ref>

====Grammy Awards==== The franchise has received a total of six [[Grammy Award]] nominations, all for films in the ''Harry Potter'' series.
{| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center" width=70% ! align="center" width="16%" | Film ! align="center" width="27%" | [[Grammy Award for Best Score Soundtrack for Visual Media|Best Score Soundtrack for Visual Media]] ! align="center" width="27%" | [[Grammy Award for Best Instrumental Composition|Best Instrumental Composition]] |- ! scope="row" | ''Philosopher's Stone'' | {{nom}}<ref name="GrammysWilliams">{{Cite web|url=https://www.grammy.com/grammys/artists/john-williams |title=John Williams |accessdate=5 July 2017 |publisher=[[The Recording Academy]]}}</ref> | {{nom}}<ref name="GrammysWilliams" /> |- ! scope="row" | ''Chamber of Secrets'' | {{nom}}<ref name="GrammysWilliams" /> | style="background-color:lightgrey;" |   |- ! scope="row" | ''Prisoner of Azkaban'' | {{nom}}<ref name="GrammysWilliams" /> | style="background-color:lightgrey;" |   |- ! scope="row" | ''Half-Blood Prince'' | {{nom}}<ref name="GrammysHooper">{{Cite web|url=https://www.grammy.com/grammys/artists/nicholas-hooper |title=Nicholas Hooper |accessdate=5 July 2017 |publisher=[[The Recording Academy]]}}</ref> | style="background-color:lightgrey;" |   |- ! scope="row" | ''Deathly Hallows – Part 2'' | {{nom}}<ref name="GrammysDesplat">{{Cite web|url=https://www.grammy.com/grammys/artists/alexandre-desplat |title=Alexandre Desplat |accessdate=5 July 2017 |publisher=[[The Recording Academy]]}}</ref> | style="background-color:lightgrey;" |   |- |}
====Laurence Olivier Awards==== ''Harry Potter and the Cursed Child'' garnered eleven [[Laurence Olivier Award]]s nominations at the [[2017 Laurence Olivier Awards|2017 ceremony]], tying the record set in [[2008 Laurence Olivier Awards|2008]] by ''[[Hairspray (musical)|Hairspray]]'', and won a record-breaking nine: [[Laurence Olivier Award for Best New Play|Best New Play]], [[Laurence Olivier Award for Best Director|Best Director]], [[Laurence Olivier Award for Best Actor|Best Actor]] (Jamie Parker), [[Laurence Olivier Award for Best Actress in a Supporting Role|Best Actress in a Supporting Role]] (Noma Dumezweni), [[Laurence Olivier Award for Best Actor in a Supporting Role|Best Actor in a Supporting Role]] (Anthony Boyle), [[Laurence Olivier Award for Best Costume Design|Best Costume Design]], [[Laurence Olivier Award for Best Set Design|Best Set Design]], [[Laurence Olivier Award for Best Sound Design|Best Sound Design]], and [[Laurence Olivier Award for Best Lighting Design|Best Lighting Design]]. The London production was also nominated for [[Laurence Olivier Award for Best Theatre Choreographer|Best Theatre Choreographer]] and [[Laurence Olivier Award for Outstanding Achievement in Music|Outstanding Achievement in Music]].<ref name="LOAnoms">{{Cite web|url=http://www.thewrap.com/harry-potter-cursed-child-breaks-olivier-awards-record-11-nominations/ |title='Harry Potter and the Cursed Child' Breaks Olivier Awards Record With 11 Nominations |work=[[TheWrap]] |last=Geier |first=Thom |date=6 March 2017 |accessdate=12 July 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170505050617/http://www.thewrap.com/harry-potter-cursed-child-breaks-olivier-awards-record-11-nominations/ |archivedate=5 May 2017 }}</ref><ref name="LOAwins">{{Cite web|url=https://www.thestage.co.uk/news/2017/olivier-awards-2017-harry-potter-and-the-cursed-child-wins-record-nine-prizes/ |title=Olivier Awards 2017: Harry Potter and the Cursed Child wins record nine prizes |work=[[The Stage]] |last=Bano |first=Tim |date=9 April 2017 |accessdate=12 July 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170415040142/https://www.thestage.co.uk/news/2017/olivier-awards-2017-harry-potter-and-the-cursed-child-wins-record-nine-prizes/ |archivedate=15 April 2017 }}</ref>
====Tony Awards==== ''Harry Potter and the Cursed Child'' received ten nominations at the [[72nd Tony Awards]], winning six awards: [[Tony Award for Best Play|Best Play]], [[Tony Award for Best Scenic Design in a Play|Best Scenic Design in a Play]], [[Tony Award for Best Costume Design in a Play|Best Costume Design in a Play]], [[Tony Award for Best Lighting Design in a Play|Best Lighting Design in a Play]], [[Tony Award for Best Sound Design|Best Sound Design of a Play]], and [[Tony Award for Best Direction of a Play|Best Direction of a Play]]. The play was also nominated for [[Tony Award for Best Actor in a Play|Best Performance by a Leading Actor in a Play]] (Parker), [[Tony Award for Best Featured Actor in a Play|Best Performance by a Featured Actor in a Play]] (Boyle), [[Tony Award for Best Featured Actress in a Play|Best Performance by a Featured Actress in a Play]] (Dumezweni), and [[Tony Award for Best Choreography|Best Choreography]].<ref name="TonyNoms">{{Cite web |url=https://variety.com/2018/legit/awards/2018-tony-awards-nominations-list-broadway-1202792611/ |title=Tony Nominations 2018: 'Mean Girls,' 'SpongeBob' Score Big (Complete List) |work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]] |last=Cox |first=Gordon |date=1 May 2018 |accessdate=2 May 2018 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180502001406/http://variety.com/2018/legit/awards/2018-tony-awards-nominations-list-broadway-1202792611/ |archivedate=2 May 2018 |df=dmy-all }}</ref><ref name="TonyWins">{{Cite web |url=https://variety.com/2018/legit/awards/tony-award-winners-2018-complete-list-1202839347/ |title=Tony Award Winners 2018: The Complete List |work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]] |last=Nyren |first=Erin |date=10 June 2018 |accessdate=11 June 2018 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180611043413/https://variety.com/2018/legit/awards/tony-award-winners-2018-complete-list-1202839347/ |archivedate=11 June 2018 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
==Outside media==
===Pottermore=== {{Main|Pottermore}} In June 2011, Rowling launched a new website announcing an upcoming project called [[Pottermore]],<ref>{{cite news|url=http://abcnews.go.com/Entertainment/wireStory?id=13858046 |title=J.K. Rowling Has Mysterious New Potter Website |publisher=[[ABC News]] |agency=[[Associated Press]] |date=16 June 2011 |accessdate=16 June 2011 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110618134045/http://abcnews.go.com/Entertainment/wireStory?id=13858046 |archivedate=18 June 2011 }}</ref> where all future ''Harry Potter'' projects, and all electronic downloads, would be concentrated.<ref>{{cite news|title=JK Rowling launches Pottermore Website |first=Anita |last=Singh |newspaper=[[The Daily Telegraph]] |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/harry-potter/8579560/JK-Rowling-launches-Pottermore-website.html |accessdate=4 July 2011 |location=London |date=16 June 2011 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110711235447/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/harry-potter/8579560/JK-Rowling-launches-Pottermore-website.html |archivedate=11 July 2011 }}</ref> Pottermore opened to the general public on 14 April 2012.<ref name="waiting">{{cite web|url=http://insider.pottermore.com/2012/03/waiting-for-pottermore.html |title=Waiting for Pottermore? |publisher=[[Pottermore]] |date=8 March 2012 |accessdate=9 March 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120310102525/http://insider.pottermore.com/2012/03/waiting-for-pottermore.html |archivedate=10 March 2012 }}</ref> Pottermore allows users to be sorted, be chosen by their wand and play various minigames. The main purpose of the website was to allow the user to journey though the story with access to content not revealed by J.{{nbsp}}K. Rowling previously, with over 18,000 words of information on characters, places and objects in the ''Harry Potter'' universe.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://newsfeed.time.com/2011/06/23/pottermore-secrets-revealed-j-k-rowlings-new-site-is-e-book-meets-interactive-world |title='Pottermore' Secrets Revealed: J.K. Rowling's New Site is E-Book Meets Interactive World |first=Sonia van |last=Gilder Cooke |date=23 June 2011 |publisher=[[Time (magazine)|Time]] |accessdate=6 January 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120829110641/http://newsfeed.time.com/2011/06/23/pottermore-secrets-revealed-j-k-rowlings-new-site-is-e-book-meets-interactive-world/ |archivedate=29 August 2012 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Pottermore website launched by JK Rowling as 'give-back' to fans |first=Alison |last=Flood |work=[[The Guardian]] |location=London |url=https://www.theguardian.com/books/2011/jun/23/pottermore-website-jk-rowling-harry-potter |accessdate=4 July 2011 |date=23 June 2011 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140715090227/http://www.theguardian.com/books/2011/jun/23/pottermore-website-jk-rowling-harry-potter |archivedate=15 July 2014 }}</ref> In September 2015, the website launched a newly designed site containing news, features and articles plus previously unreleased writing by Rowling and removed some features including the interactive Moment illustrations, House Cup and Sorting ceremony.<ref>{{cite web|title=Pottermore |url=https://www.pottermore.com/news/Welcome-to-the-new-Pottermore |publisher=[[Pottermore]] |accessdate=8 October 2015 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150926135910/https://www.pottermore.com/news/Welcome-to-the-new-Pottermore |archivedate=26 September 2015 }}</ref> A newly designed Sorting Ceremony was subsequently launched on 28 January 2016 in which users could reclaim their old house or be re-sorted.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.businessinsider.com/harry-potter-what-hogwarts-house-am-i-in-2016-1 |title=You can finally reclaim your old Hogwarts house and wand on Pottermore — here's how |work=[[Business Insider]] |date=28 January 2016 |accessdate=4 July 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161017202805/http://www.businessinsider.com/harry-potter-what-hogwarts-house-am-i-in-2016-1 |archivedate=17 October 2016 }}</ref>
===Theme park attractions=== {{Main|The Wizarding World of Harry Potter}} [[The Wizarding World of Harry Potter]] is a chain of themed areas at [[Universal Parks & Resorts]] based on the ''Harry Potter'' media franchise, adapting elements from the film series and original novels by Rowling. The areas were designed by [[Universal Creative]] under an exclusive licence with [[Warner Bros. Entertainment]].<ref name=bbc070531>{{cite news|title=Harry Potter theme park planned |newspaper=[[BBC News]] |date=31 May 2007 |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/6706939.stm?lsm |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140512225739/http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/6706939.stm?lsm |archivedate=12 May 2014 }}</ref><ref name=guardian070531>{{cite news|accessdate=19 May 2010 |title=Harry Potter theme park to open in Florida |last=Sturcke |first=James |newspaper=The Guardian |date=31 May 2007 |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2007/may/31/film.harrypotter |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130831080623/http://www.theguardian.com/world/2007/may/31/film.harrypotter |archivedate=31 August 2013 }}</ref><ref name=usatoday070531>{{cite news|title=Harry Potter theme park swoops to Fla. |newspaper=[[USA Today]] |date=31 May 2007 |url=https://www.usatoday.com/life/movies/news/2007-05-31-harry-potter-park_n.htm |accessdate=19 May 2010 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081011180722/http://www.usatoday.com/life/movies/news/2007-05-31-harry-potter-park_n.htm |archivedate=11 October 2008 }}</ref><ref name=stpetersburg070601>{{cite news |title=A whole new magic kingdom |last=Albright |first=Mark |newspaper=[[The St. Petersburg Times]] |date=1 June 2007 |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=rMUnAAAAIBAJ&sjid=g3QDAAAAIBAJ&dq=harry-potter%20theme-park%20disney&pg=2741%2C6435 |accessdate=19 May 2010}}</ref> It opened on 18 June 2010 as an expansion to the [[Islands of Adventure]] theme park at [[Universal Orlando Resort]] in Orlando, Florida,<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.orlandosentinel.com/travel/attractions/wizarding-world-of-harry-potter/os-universal-harry-potter-staying-pow20100617,0,1970029.story |title=Big day is here: Universal hopes Harry Potter's magic will last|first=Jason|last=Garcia|date=17 June 2010|accessdate=19 June 2010|newspaper=[[Orlando Sentinel]]}}</ref> and on 8 July 2014 at the [[Universal Studios Florida]] theme park.
On 15 July 2014, The Wizarding World of Harry Potter opened at the [[Universal Studios Japan]] theme park in Osaka, Japan. It includes the village of [[Hogsmeade]], the [[Harry Potter and the Forbidden Journey]] ride, and the [[Flight of the Hippogriff]] roller coaster.<ref name=orlando20140418>{{cite news|last=Bevil |first=Dewayne |date=18 April 2014 |title=Universal Studios Japan: Wizarding World of Harry Potter to open July 15 |url=http://www.orlandosentinel.com/travel/attractions/theme-park-rangers-blog/os-universal-studios-japan-harry-potter-20140418-post.html |newspaper=[[Orlando Sentinel]] |location= |publisher= |accessdate=12 September 2014 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140912073410/http://www.orlandosentinel.com/travel/attractions/theme-park-rangers-blog/os-universal-studios-japan-harry-potter-20140418-post.html |archivedate=12 September 2014 }}</ref><ref name=cnn20140716>{{cite news|last=Cripps |first=Karla |date=16 July 2014 |title=Universal Studios Japan's 'Wizarding World of Harry Potter' opens |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140912075407/http://www.cnn.com/2014/07/16/travel/universal-studios-japan-harry-potter/ |archivedate=12 September 2014 }}</ref> On 7 April 2016, The Wizarding
